contentrichtext.text: __notoc__ {{distinguish|Leonard Roth}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Klaus Roth |image = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1925|10|29|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Wrocław|Breslau]], [[Province of Lower Silesia]], [[Weimar Germany|Germany]] |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = [[United Kingdom]] |field = [[Mathematics]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = [[Theodor Estermann]] |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[diophantine approximation]]<br>[[discrepancy theory]] |prizes = [[Sylvester Medal]] (1991)<br>[[LMS De Morgan Medal]] (1983)<br>Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] (1960)<br>[[Fields Medal]] (1958) |religion = }} '''Klaus Friedrich Roth''' (born 29 October 1925) is a [[Germany|German]]-born [[United Kingdom|British]] [[mathematician]] known for work on [[diophantine approximation]], the [[large sieve]], and [[discrepancy theory|irregularities of distribution]]. He was born in [[Wrocław|Breslau]], [[Prussia]], but was raised and educated in the UK. He was pupil at St. Paul's School in London from 1939 to 1943 and then attended Cambridge University, graduating from [[Peterhouse, Cambridge]] in 1945. In 1946 he began research at [[University College London]], under the supervision of [[Theodor Estermann]]. In 1952, Roth proved that subsets of the [[integer]]s of [[Szemerédi's theorem|positive density]] must contain infinitely many [[arithmetic progression]]s of length three, thus establishing the first non-trivial case of what is now known as [[Szemerédi's theorem]]. His definitive result, now known usually as the [[Thue–Siegel–Roth theorem]], but also just ''Roth's theorem'', dates from 1955, when he was a lecturer at [[University College London]]. He was awarded a [[Fields Medal]] in 1958 on the strength of it. He became a professor at University College London in 1961, and moved to a chair at [[Imperial College London]] in 1966, a position he retained until official retirement at 1988.
